title: Blockchain Technology Fundamentals
description: Test your understanding of blockchain concepts and cryptocurrency principles
subject: Blockchain & Cryptocurrency

questions.question: What is a blockchain?
questions.prereq: Basic understanding of databases and cryptographic concepts

options.text: A distributed ledger of transactions linked using cryptography
A type of cryptocurrency
A centralized database managed by banks
A programming language for smart contracts

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of mining in a blockchain network?
questions.prereq: Knowledge of blockchain basics and consensus mechanisms

options.text: To validate transactions and create new blocks
To create new cryptocurrencies
To store transactions in a central database
options.concept: Misunderstanding mining as simple data storage

options.text: To encrypt user passwords
options.concept: Confusing mining with general cryptographic operations

questions.question: What is a smart contract?
questions.prereq: Understanding of blockchain technology and programming concepts

options.text: Self-executing code with contract terms directly written into the code
A legal document stored on the blockchain
options.concept: Confusing smart contracts with legal documents

options.text: A type of cryptocurrency wallet
An agreement between miners to validate transactions
options.concept: Confusing smart contracts with consensus mechanisms

questions.question: What is the double-spending problem?
questions.prereq: Knowledge of digital currencies and cryptographic security

options.text: The risk of spending the same digital currency twice
Spending twice as much as intended on a transaction
A type of cryptocurrency scam
options.concept: Confusing technical problems with social attacks

options.text: When transaction fees are charged twice

questions.question: What is the difference between public and private blockchains?
questions.prereq: Basic understanding of blockchain architecture and access control

options.text: Public blockchains are open to everyone, private blockchains are restricted to specific parties
options.concept: Correct understanding of blockchain access models

options.text: Public blockchains are free, private blockchains cost money
options.concept: Confusing access control with cost models

options.text: Public blockchains use proof-of-work, private blockchains use proof-of-stake
options.concept: Confusing access models with consensus mechanisms

options.text: There is no difference, they are the same thing
options.concept: Not recognizing different blockchain deployment models

questions.question: What is a hash function's role in blockchain?
questions.prereq: Advanced knowledge of cryptography and blockchain structure

options.text: To create unique fingerprints for data and link blocks together
options.concept: Correct understanding of hash functions in blockchain

options.text: To encrypt private keys for secure storage
To compress large files for efficient storage
To generate new cryptocurrency addresses
options.concept: Partially correct but missing the core blockchain linking function

blockchain-vs-cryptocurrency.description: Difficulty understanding that blockchain is the underlying technology while cryptocurrency is one application
blockchain-vs-cryptocurrency.recommendation: Study blockchain as a general-purpose distributed ledger technology with many applications beyond currency

centralized-vs-decentralized.description: Misunderstanding the decentralized nature of blockchain networks
centralized-vs-decentralized.recommendation: Learn about distributed systems, peer-to-peer networks, and the problems with centralized control

blockchain-vs-programming.description: Confusing blockchain infrastructure with programming languages or development tools
blockchain-vs-programming.recommendation: Understand blockchain as infrastructure, with smart contract languages like Solidity running on top

mining-vs-token-creation.description: Misunderstanding mining as creating new types of cryptocurrencies rather than validating existing ones
mining-vs-token-creation.recommendation: Study how mining validates transactions and secures networks, versus how new tokens are initially created

mining-vs-storage.description: Not understanding mining's role in consensus and security, seeing it as just data storage
mining-vs-storage.recommendation: Learn about consensus mechanisms, Byzantine fault tolerance, and why proof-of-work is needed

mining-vs-encryption.description: Confusing mining's specific cryptographic puzzles with general encryption operations
mining-vs-encryption.recommendation: Study the specific role of SHA-256 in proof-of-work versus other cryptographic uses

smart-vs-legal-contract.description: Misunderstanding smart contracts as legal documents rather than executable code
smart-vs-legal-contract.recommendation: Learn how smart contracts are programs that automatically execute when conditions are met

contract-vs-wallet.description: Confusing smart contracts with cryptocurrency wallets or storage mechanisms
contract-vs-wallet.recommendation: Understand that smart contracts are programs, while wallets are interfaces for managing keys and funds

contract-vs-consensus.description: Confusing smart contracts with the underlying consensus protocols
contract-vs-consensus.recommendation: Study how smart contracts run on top of consensus layers, they are different system components

double-spending-meaning.description: Misunderstanding what the double-spending problem actually means in digital currencies
double-spending-meaning.recommendation: Study why digital money differs from physical money and how blockchain prevents duplicate spending

technical-vs-social-issues.description: Confusing technical protocol problems with social engineering or scam issues
technical-vs-social-issues.recommendation: Distinguish between protocol-level technical challenges and user-facing security issues

double-spending-vs-fees.description: Confusing the double-spending problem with transaction fee or billing issues
double-spending-vs-fees.recommendation: Understand double-spending as a fundamental problem with digital money, not a fee calculation error

access-vs-cost.description: Confusing public/private access control with free/paid cost models
access-vs-cost.recommendation: Learn that access control (who can participate) is separate from cost models (who pays for what)
resources: Public vs private vs consortium blockchains

access-vs-consensus.description: Confusing who can access the blockchain with how the blockchain reaches consensus
access-vs-consensus.recommendation: Study access control (permissioned vs permissionless) separately from consensus algorithms

blockchain-type-distinction.description: Not recognizing the important differences between public, private, and consortium blockchains
blockchain-type-distinction.recommendation: Study different blockchain deployment models and their use cases

hash-vs-encryption.description: Confusing one-way hash functions with two-way encryption algorithms
hash-vs-encryption.recommendation: Learn the difference between hashing (one-way, fixed output) and encryption (two-way, variable)

hash-vs-compression.description: Misunderstanding hash functions as data compression rather than integrity verification
hash-vs-compression.recommendation: Study how hashes create fixed-size fingerprints for integrity, not space-saving compression

hash-vs-address-generation.description: Partially understanding hash use in address generation but missing the core blockchain linking function
hash-vs-address-generation.recommendation: Study how hashes serve multiple roles: linking blocks, Merkle trees, and address derivation
